author: jcarreno
title: ¿Por qué Margalida Castro estuvo internada en un manicomio? Contó que «desaparecían gente»
text:
La televisión colombiana perdió este jueves 19 de diciembre una de las actrices más preparadas y destacadas del país: Margalida Castro. Esta santandereana perdió la batalla contra el cáncer, enfermedad que le diagnosticaron hace poco, según comentó en una publicación de Instagram su mánager Claudia Serrato. Castro tuvo una carrera de más de 60 años en las artes escénicas y logró amplio reconocimiento por su participación en producciones como: ‘Gallito Ramírez’, ‘Yo Amo a Paquita Gallego’, ‘Hasta que la Plata Nos Separe’ y ‘Chepe Fortuna’.
Su carrera comenzó como flautista, luego terminó protagonizando algunas obras teatrales y estando allí fue llevada a la pantalla chica, donde claramente se destacó al punto de ganar numerosos reconocimientos. A sus 83 años Margalida decidió publicar unos libros en los que narra diferentes situaciones de su vida.
‘Margalida: del manicomio a la luz’, ‘Camisa de Fuerza’ y ‘A ti María, que tomaste vida por asalto’, fueron algunas de las obras en las que Margalida habla sobre los procesos que sufren las personas con problemas mentales y que son internadas en clínicas o centros psiquiátricos.
Ver esta publicación en Instagram
Durante una de sus últimas entrevistas, Margalida Castro reflexionó sobre la decisión de internar a un familiar en un centro psiquiátrico. Afirmó incluso que la Virgen se le apareció y le habló durante cinco horas con el propósito de dar a conocer su ‘renacimiento’.
En diálogo con el canal de Youtube ‘Senderos del Éxito’, Margalida confesó que a ella le querían hacer la ‘Lobotomía’. Comentó que al ver la película ‘Atrapado sin Salida’ de Jack Nicholson, ella recordó cómo fue tratada en un ‘manicomio’ de Sibaté donde “la salvó una enfermera suiza”.
La actriz santandereana comentó que dicha enfermera la había reconocida y la había salvado después de sufrir algunas situaciones tortuosas después de ser internada por problemas mentales. “El caso mío les parecía fascinante (…) A mí trataban de anularme y yo volvía y me les enfrentaba, a ver: aquí estoy. Yo he estado en manicomios sin cama, sin nada, reventada, a patadas y vuelta nada por las otras locas. Mordida, cogida y eso está escrito en uno de mis capítulos”, sentenció Castro.
MÁS SOBRE:
© CARACOL S.A. Todos los derechos reservados.
CARACOL S.A. realiza una reserva expresa de las reproducciones y usos de las obras y otras prestaciones accesibles desde este sitio web a medios de lectura mecánica u otros medios que resulten adecuados.

author: Duong Quang – Translated By Anh Quan
title: Fishermen have bumper catch of fish in Ha Tinh | SGGP English Edition
text: According to the chairman, on the same day, many local fishermen went out to sea about 3-5 nautical miles from shore catching tons of trieng fish and anchovies. This is the first big winning sea trip in the new year 2024, bringing a good source of income so the fishermen are very excited. Ms. Nguyen Thi Lan in Tam Hai 2 village of Ky Ninh Commune was so eager saying that at 1:00 p.m. on February 15, her family's ship arrived ashore carrying about 500kg of fresh sea anchovies, which she sold to traders for VND11,000 (US$0.45) -VND12,000 per kg. According to Ms. Lan, on the trip to the sea at the beginning of this year, many local fishermen catch a lot of anchovies and trieng fish. The total volume of fish landed by some of the ships was about 5 tons of anchovies and other vessels caught at least 400-500kg of anchovies while the maximum haul of trieng fish of some boats was about 10 tons and the minimum haul of trieng fish was 4-5 tons, sold to traders for about VND 7,000 per kg. After deducting the costs of gasoline, ice, and labor, many ships earn millions of Vietnamese dong per day.

author: Justice Nwafor
title: Revolutionizing Energy Conversion: The Era of Electrolyte-Free Fuel Cells
text: In an era where the quest for sustainable technology defines the next frontier of innovation, researchers at Aalto University have made a groundbreaking leap. They've introduced an 'electrolyte-free fuel cell' that might just be the key to unlocking an era of sustainable energy conversion. This novel technology, harnessing the 'chemovoltaic effect,' seamlessly converts renewable chemical energy and light into electricity through a GaAs diode. It's a development that promises to revolutionize our approach to energy, shifting gears from conventional fuel cells to a more sustainable, efficient paradigm. The Dawn of a New Energy Era At the heart of this innovation is the ability to directly convert chemical energy from methanol into electricity. This process, facilitated by exergonic redox reactions on semiconductor surfaces, generates electronic excitation without the need for traditional electrolytes. It's a stark departure from the limitations that have long shackled fuel cell technologies. Moreover, this approach could potentially streamline the integration of renewable energy sources into the grid, marking a significant stride toward reducing our carbon footprint. Unveiling the Secrets of Conductivity Parallel to these efforts, scientists at the University of Utah and the University of Massachusetts Amherst have shed light on the physics behind organic semiconductor conductivity. Their research delves into the interactions between dopants and polymers, unraveling the mystery behind the inconsistent conductivity of organic materials. They discovered that when the system is inundated with enough dopants, electrons band together to counteract the attractive forces that hinder electrical current flow. This insight not only paves the way for higher conductivity in organic materials but also opens the door to the development of flexible electronics, a field that traditional inorganic semiconductors have struggled to penetrate due to their rigid nature. A Leap Towards Flexible, Sustainable Electronics The implications of these discoveries are far-reaching. With organic materials offering a cheaper, more flexible alternative to their inorganic counterparts, the future of electronics could see a significant shift. The advancements in Organic Electrochemical Transitors (OECTs) and the use of Organic Mixed Ionic Electronic Conductors (OMIECs) as channel materials highlight the strides being made towards improving device operation and expanding the materials library of mixed conductors. This not only promises high-performance individual devices but also the potential for larger integrated circuits that could revolutionize various industries, from healthcare to renewable energy. As the world continues to grapple with the challenges of climate change and the urgent need for sustainable solutions, these breakthroughs offer a glimmer of hope. They represent not just the culmination of years of research but also the beginning of a new chapter in our journey towards a greener, more sustainable future. The advancements in electrolyte-free fuel cells, alongside the revelations about organic semiconductor conductivity, underscore the potential of scientific innovation to address some of the most pressing issues of our time. As we move forward, it's clear that the path towards a sustainable future is not just a dream, but an achievable reality, thanks to the relentless pursuit of knowledge and the unwavering commitment to innovation.

author: Lucca
title: Questo terreno sta lentamente bruciando, rilasciando CO2: ecco cosa si rischia con le torbiere
text:
[SCIENZA](https://tecnologia.libero.it/scienza/)
Questo terreno sta lentamente bruciando, rilasciando CO2: ecco cosa si rischia con le torbiere
Un terreno sta bruciando lentamente a causa di un particolare processo: si tratta di una torbiera dragata che rilascia così tanta CO2 da incidere sul cambiamento climatico
In Germania un terreno sta lentamente bruciando: si tratta di una torbiera ed è molto pericolosa per l’ambiente.
In questo tipo di terreni si depositano quantità incredibili di carbonio che contribuiscono in maniera significativa al cambiamento climatico.
Il ruolo delle torbiere nel cambiamento climatico
Lungo la costa del Mar Baltico, in Germania, un campo di fieno nasconde un confine invisibile tra due mondi: uno è fatto di terreno minerale, composto da sabbia e argilla, l’altro è una torbiera, ossia un ecosistema unico composto da vegetazione antica compressa nel tempo. Questi terreni, che coprono circa il 3% della superficie terrestre, custodiscono una quantità sorprendente di carbonio, superiore a quella contenuta in tutte le foreste del mondo messe insieme. Ma quando vengono drenati per l’agricoltura, diventano una fonte di [emissioni di CO2](https://tecnologia.libero.it/stiamo-superando-triste-record-picco-emissioni-gas-serra-95260), contribuendo al [cambiamento climatico](https://tecnologia.libero.it/qualita-dell-aria-sta-peggiorando-91527) in modo significativo.
Le torbiere, spesso trascurate nel dibattito climatico, sono straordinariamente vulnerabili. Una volta dragate, l’ossigeno penetra nel suolo, attivando una sorta di combustione lenta che rilascia carbonio nell’atmosfera. Questo fenomeno è paragonabile alla combustione del carbone, ma senza il fumo visibile: una minaccia silenziosa e impercettibile. Ogni ettaro di torbiera bonificata può emettere fino a 12 tonnellate di CO2 all’anno, un valore equivalente a quello prodotto percorrendo 40.000 chilometri con un’auto a benzina.
Un esempio emblematico si trova nello stato tedesco di Meclemburgo-Pomerania Anteriore, dove il drenaggio delle torbiere rappresenta il 40% delle emissioni totali di gas serra della regione. A livello nazionale, queste terre contribuiscono al 7% delle emissioni totali della Germania. E il problema non è circoscritto a questa zona: le torbiere si trovano in tutto il mondo, dalle coste del Pacifico alle isole dell’Atlantico, passando per l’Europa settentrionale, la Siberia e il Nord America.
Come circoscrivere il problema
Le tecniche di drenaggio, sviluppate secoli fa, hanno trasformato le torbiere in terreni agricoli fertili grazie a un sistema di canali, pompe e dighe che mantengono asciutta la terra. Tuttavia, questa trasformazione ha un costo elevato per il clima. La Germania, uno dei Paesi più colpiti dal fenomeno, ha già drenato quasi tutte le sue torbiere naturali. Eppure, c’è una strada percorribile per invertire la rotta: restituire l’acqua a queste aree.
Un progetto attivato vicino alla città di Greifswald ha dimostrato che è possibile farlo. Qui, circa 30 anni fa, le autorità locali hanno spostato una diga e spento le pompe, permettendo all’acqua di tornare a invadere una torbiera. Da allora, le emissioni di CO2 si sono fermate e la vegetazione tipica delle zone umide ha iniziato a ricrescere, intrappolando carbonio nell’atmosfera e creando nuovi strati di torba. Questo esempio alimenta la speranza che la riqualificazione delle torbiere possa essere una soluzione efficace contro il cambiamento climatico.
Nonostante i successi appena citati, riportare l’acqua nelle torbiere è una sfida articolata. Molti terreni drenati ora sono di proprietà di agricoltori che li utilizzano per il pascolo o la coltivazione. Cambiare il loro utilizzo richiede un equilibrio delicato tra conservazione e produttività. Alcuni ricercatori propongono soluzioni innovative, come l’uso di colture tradizionali delle zone umide, come le [canne palustri](https://tecnologia.libero.it/phragmites-minaccia-invisibile-zone-umide-95115), o trattori progettati per operare su terreni bagnati. Tuttavia, molti agricoltori rimangono scettici, citando difficoltà economiche e tecniche.
Un compromesso potrebbe essere identificare aree agricole poco redditizie, come il 10% delle torbiere drenate, per riportarle al loro stato naturale. Le autorità locali potrebbero facilitare il processo offrendo compensazioni economiche o scambi di terreni pubblici. In Germania, circa 5.000 ettari di torbiere vengono recuperati ogni anno grazie a programmi finanziati dal governo, ma tutto ciò rappresenta solo una piccola frazione di quello che sarebbe necessario per raggiungere gli obiettivi climatici del Paese.
Per rispettare il suo impegno di ridurre le emissioni nette a zero entro il 2050, la Germania dovrebbe ripristinare oltre 40.000 ettari di torbiere ogni anno. Si tratta di un obiettivo ambizioso che richiede un’azione coordinata e investimenti significativi, ma è fondamentale per mitigare gli effetti del cambiamento climatico.
La protezione e il ripristino delle torbiere rappresentano un’opportunità unica per il mondo: non solo fermare una fonte di emissioni di carbonio, ma anche trasformare queste terre in veri e propri magazzini naturali di carbonio. Affrontare questa sfida richiede coraggio politico, innovazione tecnologica e la volontà di ripensare il rapporto con il territorio, in equilibrio tra produzione e sostenibilità.

author: A_S
title: #19 Fe, familia y odio al progresismo: el poder de los evangélicos latinos se extiende por Estados Unidos
text:
[blodhemn](/user/blodhemn)a [elpais.com](/go/link/3942841) [#4](c4#c-4) Es una manera de verlo. Otra es que unos cuantos españoles se han marchado a países menos corruptos, han visto que se vive mejor así y evitan votar a los partidos que mantienen aquí niveles indecentes de corrupción.
Pero hay de todo…
[#4](c4#c-4) te recomiendo algo más de fibra en tu dieta, parece que aún no has digerido el que no ganaran los tuyos
[#4](c4#c-4) que yo conozca la gente que emigra a EEUU normalmente son gente con títulos superiores donde irse a América es muy buena opción laboral, y ya esta, si votan a la izquierda española sera porque ven desde fuera que es mejor opción.
Que pasa con los que votan a la derecha?
Que significaria?
Por cierto a mayor nivel de estudios el votante de izquierda aumenta, tampoco dices nada de eso?
Y los testigos de Jehová. Antes estaban a la salida de los hospitales con sus plafones. Ahora los veo en: la salida del metro, de los parques y en cualquier esquina o paseo. De 3 en 3. Si no les miras no te molestan, al menos en mi experiencia, pero me parece preocupante cómo van invadiendo el espacio público para su negocio de proselitismo religioso. ¿Puedo plantar un plafón con folletos de mi empresa 7 u 8 horas allá dónde me apetezca y abordar a los transeúntes?
[#3](c3#c-3) al igual que llevan toda la vida ocupando espacio publico los mendigos, los que reparten folletos, los grupos de turistas guiados.... mientras la ocupacion no sea permanente, no hay problema
[#3](c3#c-3) En mi pequeña ciudad de 40k habitantes el otro día me crucé a cuatro así, todos eran latinos. Les dije con palabras poco amables que se fueran con sus historias a su templo, que la calle no era lugar para ello. Eran muy ridículos, hablaban con una grandiosidad típica de pastor evangélico y que si la gloria de dios y mierdas así. Llamé a la policía. Me parece sumamente preocupante esto. Uno de ellos aún venía con ese falso buen rollo a "debatir" conmigo y me hacía preguntas de lo más ridículas. Largo de la calle por favor.
Yo lo llamaría "fe seudocristiana", porque muchas veces esto no está movido por una fe religiosa, sino que la fe religiosa es solo el medio para mover otra cosa, por ejemplo, mantener a la gente distraída odiando el aborto o a los homosexuales mientras no se dan cuenta de que otros se están quedando con la mayor parte de su esfuerzo al trabajar.
La religión era prácticamente la única cosa de LATAM que EEUU no controlaba, pero con el evangelismo es probable que en una década o dos reemplace al catolicismo en cantidad de seguidores.

author: TW Starr
title: Human medical technology helping chimps at Chimp Haven
text:
Chimp getting an echocardiogram
KEITHVILLE, La. - Heart disease is not just a major concern for people. Did you know that heart disease is also a top killer for some or our closest living relatives, the chimpanzee?
Now state-of-the-art human medical technology is helping in inhabitants of Chimp Haven live longer.
echocardiogram
Why is this important? Cardiovascular disease is the leading cause of death in chimpanzees.
The veterinary staff at Chimp Haven in Keithville recently gained some invaluable tools and knowledge in their fight to give the animals in their care the best life possible. They have teamed up with the Great Ape Heart Project to give life extending care.
Dr. Raven Jackson, Chimp Haven's veterinary care director.
"We have an aging population. Chimpanzees are considered geriatric once they reach the age of 35 or greater, we have more than 300 chimpanzees and we figured this would be a great partnership," said Dr. Raven Jackson, Chimp Haven's veterinary care director.
What they embarked upon was giving echocardiograms to as many chimps as they could in just two days.
Dr. Trevor Gerlach of the Great Ape Heart Project
"An echocardiogram is a ultrasound of the heart. Essentially the machine will project ultrasonic sound and that sound will bounce off a tissue and come back to the machine and make a picture," said Dr. Trevor Gerlach of the Great Ape Heart Project.
Dr. Shaunte Coleman, Chimp Haven veterinarian
"It helps us to see how the valves work with each individual chimpanzee and that information basically helps us to guide our care for them," said Dr. Shaunte Coleman, Chimp Haven veterinarian.
They found that most of the chiimps had mild cardiac conditions. But one named Jake had severe cardiac abnormalities. He will now get regular EKG's and blood pressure medications that most often are prescribed to humans with similar diagnosis.
There's over 300 of these chimpanzees at the sanctuary and so far only seven have been given an echocardiogram. But, the staff at Chimp Haven hope in time to eventually get through the entire colony.
"Within three years we should have at least one echo on each individual, and then we'll continue to incorporate it on into their physical examination, whether that be within the one- to three-year cycle," said Jackson.
Chimp Haven
Chimp Haven and the Great Ape Heart Project have found this to be a mutually beneficial project that they hope will continue long into the future.
"We love facilities like this because not only do we on our end get to collect information on the species, we take that information and upload it into a database where we've collected information from chimpanzees from all over the world. As far as Chimp Haven they benefit from contributing to a larger body of research. They also get feedback from us and we can say hey this animal has a dilated heart and would be best managed with these medications going forward," said Gerlach.
Report a typo on this article

author: , The Asheville Citizen Times
title: High water closes Parson Branch Road, Hyatt Lane, Ramsey Prong Road
text: The aftermath of severe storms earlier this week continues to cause problems on roads in the Great Smoky Mountains. Parson Branch Road, Hyatt Lane, and Ramsey Prong Road remain closed May 10 due to high water, according to the Smokies Road Info account on X , formerly known as Twitter. Cades Cove Loop Road and Greenbrier Road are now open. Ramsey Cascades Trail will remain closed May 10-12. Weather conditions prevented trail crews from completing planned work on a footlog bridge this week and need to keep the trail closed for visitor safety, the National Park Service announced May 9. Hikers throughout the park are advised to use caution over the next few days because of downed trees and some flooding caused by the storms and heavy rain. Severe storms rolled through East Tennessee earlier this week, bringing heavy winds and dumping up to 4 inches of rain across the region within a 24-hour period. During the storms, a Tazewell man died after a tree fell on a vehicle, and a warehouse roof collapse in Knox County, causing a massive gas leak and minor injuries to two people. Devarrick Turner is a trending news reporter. Email [devarrick.turner@knoxnews.com](mailto:devarrick.turner@knoxnews.com). On X, formerly known as Twitter @dturner1208 . Support strong local journalism by subscribing at knoxnews.com/subscribe .

author: @speedwaydigest
title: Hagar Captures Podium Result for Three Different Car Owners
text:
Derek Hagar guided three different race cars to podium performances last weekend.
Hagar swept the 305ci winged sprint car portion of the show at Crowleys Ridge Raceway in Paragould, Ark., on Friday in a McCord Farms sprint car.
“We had a really good car all night long,” he said. “We won the heat race and took the lead on the initial start of the feature and never looked back. I was able to run the top in turns one and two up on the dirt wall. It really helped me launch off the corner and hit the bottom in turns three and four. We got to lapped traffic and I had to start moving around. I figured out the middle worked pretty good for me in turns three and four and I was still able to run the top in turns one and two.”
Hagar also hopped in a 600cc micro sprint that night for Marshall Skinner Motorsports, winning a heat race and placing second in the main event.
“It was fun,” he said. “We won the heat race and started outside pole in the feature. Jackson (Skinner) got by me on the first lap. He and the guy on the pole were side by side the whole race. Jackson finally cleared him and ran the best race I’ve seen him run. A 12-year-old kid with me behind him, I figured he’d start overdriving the car, but he didn’t. I gave it all I had to get around him and just couldn’t make it happen.”
Hagar then climbed aboard the Paul Hart owned 410ci winged sprint car on Saturday and Sunday at Lake Ozark Speedway, which hosted a POWRi 410 Outlaw Sprint Series doubleheader. He qualified 20 th quickest before rallying from seventh to fourth place in a heat race on Saturday to lock into the main event. Hagar capped the night by charging from 12 th to second place in the A Main, marking the second-most cars passed.
“We drew the highest pill and went out last in qualifying,” he said. “We were still trying to learn the car. The heat race came around and we made some changes. We charged our way forward three spots. The cushion was really treacherous. I made my mind up I was running the middle to the bottom in the feature. I started picking cars off left and right. The double-file restarts were key for us. I picked the outside every time even if I gave up a position because I could get a really good launch up top coming off turn four. We worked our way up to second.”
The weekend concluded with another rally on Sunday. After timing in 14 th quickest and ending fifth in a heat race, Hagar maneuvered from 16 th to sixth in the feature. The 10 positions gained were the most and earned the Hard Charger Award.
“There really wasn’t passing in the heat races,” he said. “I made the bottom work good at the start of the feature. Once I got up to sixth the track started rubbering up by Lap 8 or 9. It was follow the leader for the rest of the race.”
Hagar plans to return to action this Saturday at Farmington Empire Speedway in Farmington, Mo., during the 27 th annual Queens Royal and Terry Babb Tribute.
QUICK RESULTS –
Aug. 30 – Crowleys Ridge Raceway in Paragould, Ark. (305 sprint car) – Heat race: 1 (2); Feature: 1 (1).
Aug. 30 – Crowleys Ridge Raceway in Paragould, Ark. (600cc micro sprint) – Heat race: 1 (2); Feature: 2 (2).
Aug. 31 – Lake Ozark Speedway in Eldon, Mo. – Qualifying: 20; Heat race: 4 (7); Feature: 2 (12).
Sept. 1 – Lake Ozark Speedway in Eldon, Mo. – Qualifying: 14; Heat race: 5 (5); Feature: 6 (16).
SEASON STATS –
25 races, 8 wins, 16 top fives, 20 top 10s, 22 top 15s, 22 top 20s
UP NEXT –
Saturday at Farmington Empire Speedway in Farmington, Mo., for the 27 th annual Queens Royal and Terry Babb Tribute
ILP PR
